description: Nikola Petrak, leveraging his knowledge from years managing Council processes, quietly instructs system overseers to suspend selective BCI controls. He formally authorizes recognition of Memory Markets and Shadow Ballot districts as zones of legitimate civic expression.
With Council paralyzed, Memory Markets flourish in former low-visibility areas. Citizens submit stories and rank values, while local officials observe but do not intervene.

Spurred by the mass participation, the Council—under pressure from both Petrak’s act and public momentum—announces a rare citywide assembly. Faction leaders clash on live broadcast, as residents demand role in future governance.
Districts formally use the Shadow Ballot to set local priorities. Initial results reveal stark differences: some neighborhoods prioritize safety, others autonomy or fairness.
Stenograd splits into self-governing enclaves based on Shadow Ballot outcomes, each with its own BCI adjustments. Council’s authority wanes as power shifts to neighborhood assemblies.
